results.title: Rose against the odds
results.creator_credit: Ross Close, Russell Kennedy, John Dixon and Onset Productions
results.brief_description: The fate of Australia’s most prominent Aboriginal boxer, Lionel Rose, is charted here in dramatic detail and enacted by Paul Williams. Roses’ career culminated in 1968 when the then unknown 19 year old became world bantamweight champion. His success made him a household name and national hero with people from all walks of life. It was not a path paved in gold however, as battles with alcohol would mar his ultimately triumphant life. Cast also includes Telly Savalas, Tsurutaro, Kris McQuade, Tony Barry, Vicki Blanche and Steve Jacobs.

results.title: In search of pure colour: Pierre Bonnard 1867-1947
results.creator_credit: Didier Baussy, Antenne-2, Centre National D'Artes de Culture and RM Arts
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Phaidon art collection”.
Pierre Bonnard was amongst one of the Nabi artists known to kick start French painting into modernism. Nick-named “The Japanese Nabi” for his predilection to things Japanese - exploring his love for line, colour and division of space, remained an inspiration throughout Bonnard’s life. Mostly working from his home overlooking Cannes, Bonnard spent his life in search of ‘pure colour’ wanting “to show what you see when you suddenly burst into a room”. This documentary describes Bonnard’s relationship with contemporary artists such as Gauguin, Matisse, Cezanne, Seurat and Renoir, his personal relationship with his models and his personal vision expressed through his paintings and sketchbooks. A life dedicated to ‘colour, form and reason’ over content and feeling.

results.title: Rose's house
results.creator_credit: Clay Borris and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: This film takes an unvarnished look at life in a working-class district of Toronto. Based on the filmmaker’s memories of his mother’s boarding house in Cabbagetown, Toronto, this docudrama revolves around Rose and how she runs her establishment. With a household as full and varied as hers, where the marginal mix with the straight, situations arise that require immediate action. For bootlegging, violence, and stealing, Rose hands out her own brand of justice. Even authority isn’t exempt: she becomes involved in a noisy dispute with a social worker over her son’s theft of a bicycle. Cast: Rose Maltais-Borris, Albert Borris, Ronald Maltais, Garry Borris, John Brown, Magella Joseph, George Martell, Paulette Jiles, Edmond Charest.

results.title: Isamu Noguchi
results.creator_credit: Bruce W. Bassett and Whitgate Productions Ltd
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Phaidon art collection”.
Isamu Noguchi (1904-88) was one of the world’s leading sculptors of the 20th century. By rights American, residing in both Long Island and the Japanese island Shikoku, Noguchi throughout the documentary makes reference to his ‘nomadic’ life influenced by his family upbringing and this relationship to his work. Throughout the documentary, Noguchi explores his relationship with place, sculpture and stone (his chosen material) discussing freely his ideas and motivations. Some of his large scale commissions from the 60’s to the late 70’s are featured in locations as varied as Paris, Detroit, Japan and Mexico City along with the sets he designed for Martha Graham’s dance “Cortege of Eagles” (see 16mm film title #015721 of the same title). Written, directed and narrated by Bruce W. Bassett, this documentary features some iconic photography by Bruce G. Sparks that captures the spirit of the time reflecting the value of Noguchi’s legacy.

results.title: Vermeer: light, love and silence
results.creator_credit: Michael Gill, Malone Gill Productions and RM Arts
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Phaidon art collection”.
Written, produced, directed by Michael Gill and presented by Melvyn Bragg “Light, love and silence” focuses on the artist Jan Vermeer’s painting style and his intimate depictions of domestic interiors. Little known outside Holland for almost 200 years after his death, he is now considered one of the greatest painters of the seventeenth century. This documentary examines his paintings through detailed descriptions and discusses his technical skill, use of perspective and extraordinary understanding of light guided by the use of a camera obscura. Although very little is known about this intriguing artist for he left no letters, drawings or clues relating to the intention of his paintings, interviews with academics including Dr Jonathon Miller and Svetlana Alpers provide a greater insight into the social, political and scientific environment in which he worked.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Michael Gill, Malone Gill Productions and RM Arts

results.title: Rosanna: a portrait of an immigrant woman
results.creator_credit: Sharon McGowan, Shelah Reljic and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Rosanna Santamaria arrived in Canada in 1969. A single parent supporting three children, she had to adapt to a new marital status, a new country, and a new language. Although she faced added difficulties as an immigrant, her problems are common to many women. She is now working to help others like herself make the transition to a new life.
results.title_for_label: Rosanna: a portrait of an immigrant woman
results.creator_credit_for_label: Sharon McGowan, Shelah Reljic and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Three colours Cezanne
results.creator_credit: Janice Sutherland, BBC and RM Arts
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Phaidon art collection”.
Cezanne is widely understood as “the father of modernism”. It was Cezanne’s studies of structure in the landscape that acted as a precursor to cubism and abstraction in the 20th Century. In his lifetime however he was much maligned by the critics and public alike and would often retreat into a rural solitary existence. His difficult relationship with his father and strained family life resulted in a lifelong struggle for happiness and determined much of his personal difficulties. This documentary details his ‘constant’ emotional struggles alongside his working career and draws on the observations of a number of contemporary artists and historians to help us understand how complex Cezanne’s life was to his art. Commentaries by: Bridget Riley, Howard Hodgkin, R.B. Kitaj, Joseph Rishal, critic John Golding and granddaughter, Aline Cezanne.

group_works.title: Graeme Bell
group_works.creator_credit: Frank Heimans, Sharon Connolly and Film Australia

results.title: Rosalie Kunoth-Monks
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian biography”.
Rosalie Kunoth-Monks: Aboriginal activist, actor, social worker, Parliamentary Candidate 1979-1981, President Aboriginal Legal Aid NT 1983-87, 1990-93, was born in Utopia, Central Australia, 1937 and is of German Aboriginal parentage. Kunoth-Monks discusses her education at St Mary’s Children’s Hostel, Alice Springs, and on being discovered by Charles and Elsa Chauvel as the lead in “Jedda”. She talks about working on the film, and her family’s response to it, in particular the sexual references. A greater passion was to help people, and Rosalie joined the Community of the Holy Name in Melbourne and was a nun for ten years, also gaining training during this period in childcare. Working as an Aboriginal liaison officer in Victoria after leaving the sisterhood, Kunoth-Monks also established the first Aboriginal Family Group home, in addition to marrying during this period. A return to Central Australia saw her working for the Country Liberal Party and being active in social welfare before she returned, full circle, to Utopia.

group_siblings.title: Graeme Bell

results.title: Monsieur Rene Magritte
results.creator_credit: Adrian Maben, Neil Mundy, Antenne-2, RM Productions and WDR
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Phaidon art collection”.
About the life of Belgium artist Rene Magritte, one of the most famous of all surrealists. The documentary discusses his personal life and the motivations behind his art. Obsessed with the everyday, Magritte’s practise was to reinvent the ordinary by changing the ‘viewers’ perception. “It’s not the painting that changes your perception, it’s the thoughts triggered when looking at the work that does”. As a metaphysical painter like his mentor De Chirico, Magritte sought to make reality and meaning represented as visionary not literal - it’s this legacy that is explored in this documentary.
